Over-the-counter drugs.  

Store-brand ibuprofen is literally the exact same thing as Advil.  

Acetaminophen = Tylenol.  

And so on.

post.title: What's a product where it's alright to settle for the cheaper version?

body: Strongly disagree on this one. Enthusiast interests (power, handling, steering feel, etc) aside, the comfort and build quality varies greatly and your enjoyment will vary along side the things. Also, reliability and repair costs for a cheap car can potentially more than offset what you saved vs. a more reputable brand up front.
body_html: Strongly disagree on this one. Enthusiast interests (power, handling, steering feel, etc) aside, the comfort and build quality varies greatly and your enjoyment will vary along side the things. Also, reliability and repair costs for a cheap car can potentially more than offset what you saved vs. a more reputable brand up front.

body: Agreed. You're wasting your time trying to save money on toothpicks if you have a $30k+ car. You need to consider the absolute amount of money saved and not a percentage. It doesn't matter to get 50% off of something that only cost $1 in the first place.

post.title: What's a product where it's alright to settle for the cheaper version?

body: Yes as a matter of fact with medicine it is basically illegal to cheap out on the ingredients. That is added to the fact that big name drug companies are required to be transparent in their production process and can't hide behind secret ingredients. So, generic brand drugs are essentially exact clones of the brand name stuff. However drugs are still protected by patent law, so generic brands cannot come along until about 15 years later. Usually pharmaceutical companies will react to their expired patents by adding or changing one single ingredient that has no effect on the medicine, then re-patenting it.
body_html: Yes as a matter of fact with medicine it is basically illegal to cheap out on the ingredients. That is added to the fact that big name drug companies are required to be transparent in their production process and can't hide behind secret ingredients. So, generic brand drugs are essentially exact clones of the brand name stuff. However drugs are still protected by patent law, so generic brands cannot come along until about 15 years later. Usually pharmaceutical companies will react to their expired patents by adding or changing one single ingredient that has no effect on the medicine, then re-patenting it.

post.title: What's a product where it's alright to settle for the cheaper version?

body: That sounds really vague and uneducated tbh. Most spitfires are hard like 99a that are supposed to be slick for skate parks. I have OJs and had them since my first cruiser, they're usually soft and gummy, because that's their job. Trick wheels and tranny skating uses hard wheels and cruising usually uses more like 78a for super soft or 85 or something for a mixture. I still have my spitfire 56mm 98a on my trick board and have for the past 3 years. OJs, especally the Hot Juice tend to chunk and fall apart way faster.

post.title: What's a product where it's alright to settle for the cheaper version?

body: Don't get me wrong. I usually drink tap water anyway, because the low cost appeals to me more than the flavor. Though to be fair, tap-water can vary like crazy from place to place. Different areas have different ordinances for how to keep the water clean. In college, I remember I could basically taste the fluorine in the water, and if you froze it all the fluorine would rise to the top in a concentrated form.

post.title: What's a product where it's alright to settle for the cheaper version?

body:
That's fair, but if one car is an up front "below the elbow" cut and another is just at the wrist today*, is it the better deal? Especially when one offers you a solid, comfortable cabin to enjoy over the next several years and the other is a chintzy rattling deathtrap.

All I'm saying is that a really cheap car can be both really cheap in terms of what you get, and not that cheap in terms of what you end up spending in the long run,  so to me cars do not fit this question. 

I will say that more expensive doesn't always mean better car, (luxury brands tend to be money pits) but often a car that's maybe $2k more than a direct competitor ends up being $2k well spent.

*plus few inches in 40k miles when the suspension fails, and a few more 30k after that when the transmission goes out, and eventually even your shoulder is gone

post.title: What's a product where it's alright to settle for the cheaper version?

body:
I used to feel this way until I bought a particularly bad variety of generic antihistamines in a blister pack.
You know, the kind of pack where (in theory) you just press one side of the bubble with your thumb and the pill neatly pops out the other end.
The blaster pack was so badly designed that the first time I tried to pop out a pill, I basically ground it into a powder and had to give up and use scissors in the end anyway.

So I'd add a caveat to this one: if you go generic, don't get the blister pack.

post.title: What's a product where it's alright to settle for the cheaper version?

body:
Do as little research, and you can be completely sure it's the same thing. For example, Post cereals fill up the issue time on their lines with store brand products. General Mills does not. So your knockoff Honey Groups of O's will likely be made at the same factory while your Cheerios be knockoff won't.

Source: cereal snob.

author.bio: Professional IT, Radio and Electronics technician, 15+ years experience.  III%.  Youngest old fart you'll ever meet.

body:
I upvoted but VEHEMENTLY disagree.  When it comes to parts, you absolutely get what you pay for.  Buying a computer outright, whether it be a laptop or a desktop, consult with someone who knows computers really well because you might save $150 on buying a laptop with an AMD processor vs an Intel processor but that AMD isn't nearly as powerful as you think it is and runs like shit.  If you're buying a pre-built gaming computer pay your friend to help you build it and buy the damn parts individually, you will spend like HALF THE PRICE.

Processors, routers, GPUs, motherboards all cost more because you are getting not only more longevity but more performance.  You 100% are paying more for a reason.
body_html:
I upvoted but VEHEMENTLY disagree. When it comes to parts, you absolutely get what you pay for. Buying a computer outright, whether it be a laptop or a desktop, consult with someone who knows computers really well because you might save $150 on buying a laptop with an AMD processor vs an Intel processor but that AMD isn't nearly as powerful as you think it is and runs like shit. If you're buying a pre-built gaming computer pay your friend to help you build it and buy the damn parts individually, you will spend like HALF THE PRICE.

Processors, routers, GPUs, motherboards all cost more because you are getting not only more longevity but more performance. You 100% are paying more for a reason.

parent.body: Yes as a matter of fact with medicine it is basically illegal to cheap out on the ingredients. That is added to the fact that big name drug companies are required to be transparent in their production process and can't hide behind secret ingredients. So, generic brand drugs are essentially exact clones of the brand name stuff. However drugs are still protected by patent law, so generic brands cannot come along until about 15 years later. Usually pharmaceutical companies will react to their expired patents by adding or changing one single ingredient that has no effect on the medicine, then re-patenting it.
parent.body_html: Yes as a matter of fact with medicine it is basically illegal to cheap out on the ingredients. That is added to the fact that big name drug companies are required to be transparent in their production process and can't hide behind secret ingredients. So, generic brand drugs are essentially exact clones of the brand name stuff. However drugs are still protected by patent law, so generic brands cannot come along until about 15 years later. Usually pharmaceutical companies will react to their expired patents by adding or changing one single ingredient that has no effect on the medicine, then re-patenting it.

post.title: What's a product where it's alright to settle for the cheaper version?

body:
I have several crappy tools that I use occasionally, but they still work fine.  I'll replace the tool with a higher-end model if I use it so often it breaks, or if the crappy version doesn't do the job well enough.

A good friend of mine has a $20 Harbor Freight chinesium drill.  The chuck is not anywhere near centered, but it's great for stupid stuff where you wouldn't want to risk damaging a nicer drill.  We've smoked it out more than once, but it still works fine.

post.title: What's a product where it's alright to settle for the cheaper version?

body: I can think of many examples where you might not want to use a nicer cordless drill.  Drilling large holes is better done with a corded drill because you won't be stopping every 5 minutes to change batteries.  You also risk overheating the motor, and I personally care a lot more about burning out my Makita than some Harbor Freight monstrosity.  If you're drilling through wood that could have nails in it, you risk damaging the gear train of the drill by stopping it suddenly.  Working in a very dusty environment can cause dust to enter the drill and gum up the insides or clog the air intakes.
body_html: I can think of many examples where you might not want to use a nicer cordless drill. Drilling large holes is better done with a corded drill because you won't be stopping every 5 minutes to change batteries. You also risk overheating the motor, and I personally care a lot more about burning out my Makita than some Harbor Freight monstrosity. If you're drilling through wood that could have nails in it, you risk damaging the gear train of the drill by stopping it suddenly. Working in a very dusty environment can cause dust to enter the drill and gum up the insides or clog the air intakes.
